answers.body_markdown:
You are getting the free space (using query) from the table but the high watermark is still at the point from where you can not insert data below that.

You need to reclaim that space using the following:

    alter table your_table enable row movement;
    
    alter table your_table shrink space cascade;

Also, You will need to rebuild the indexes of the table after such an operation.

Refer [Oracle documentation][1] for reclaiming waste space.

Cheers!!


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/server.111/b28310/schema003.htm
answers.title: Oracle not reuse deleted blocks

items.body_markdown:
With Service Fabric, you define run-time settings / environment variables via the service manifests, and optionally override them in the application manifest or even as application instance parameters at creation time.

Then, with Service Fabric you can access those settings via either `CodePackageActivationContext.GetConfigurationPackageObject("Config")` or you can use environment variables that Service Fabric will populate for your running process when it starts it.

Refer: 

* [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33928204/where-do-you-set-and-access-run-time-configuration-parameters-per-environment][1]
* [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-fabric/service-fabric-manage-multiple-environment-app-configuration][2]

My question / concern surrounds the environment variables approach, specifically about the security / safety of that information. For example:

* Security caveats - could I consider it as on par with app.config constraints?
* Are this environment variables visible to just my service process instance?
 (or would another process that executes under the same default NT SERVICES\NETWORK account also see the same)
* Mutability? Can it change? Can another process change it?

I would like to place connection string information in a Service Fabric environment variable for our services, mainly because it allows me to retrieve it using `System.Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable(...)` instead of having reference sprawl of the Service Fabric SDK assemblies in projects not really focused on Service Fabric concerns (layered application design).

*PS: app.config/web.config is not an option for us because we use the same code and version under multiple instances in clusters and each instance would have different connection information.*


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33928204/where-do-you-set-and-access-run-time-configuration-parameters-per-environment
  [2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-fabric/service-fabric-manage-multiple-environment-app-configuration
items.title: Is it safe to use Service Fabric environment variables for run-time settings like a connection string?

answers.body_markdown:
What is happening is that each time you click there is an event AND value emitted to the parent component, the parent component has a listener `v-on:del-todo` means it is listening on the `del-todo` event, once it is triggered/handled it emits it again one level up until it reaches the component where you want to actually manipulate the data (delete the item based on id).   
**Note**: the value is implicitly passed into the handler function `deleteTodo` so even though it is not explicitly there (i.e. `deleteTodo($event)` it is there.
answers.title: Why does this event actually trigger?

answers.body_markdown: In Vue.js there are not only the events `click` `change` and `input`, it also allows you to define custom events. All you have to do ist throw an event in the child-component with `$emit('my-custom-event', param1, param2)` and catch it in the direct parent-component with `v-on:my-custom-event="handler"` (you can also write `@my-custom-event`, thats synonym). The handler is a function that takes the parameters passed when emitting the event. Your handler in the `Todos`-component catches the event `del-todo` and throws a new event with the same name. The `Home`-component catches that event and has its function `deleteTodo` defined as its handler, so this function is being called (the id that was passed with the event is the parameter for `deleteTodo`).
answers.title: Why does this event actually trigger?

answers.body_markdown:
While on Windows two differently cased file names always point to the same file, on other platforms they do not. This means that imports with different file names are treated as different modules, this is by design and is not considered an issue ([see here for node discussion](https://github.com/nodejs/node-v0.x-archive/issues/6000))

The simple solution is to force consistent file casing to be used when importing modules. Typescript does have a compiler option to force this named `forceConsistentCasingInFileNames` ([See docs](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html)). This option should prevent such issues.
answers.title: Static data initialised twice due to typo in import in TypeScript

One option you have is to use the [Confluent Hub tool][1] to install the connector - you can you use it without running Confluent Platform IIRC: 

    confluent-hub install mongodb/kafka-connect-mongodb:0.2

The Confluent Hub tool handles stuff like `plugin.path` automagically so that you don't have to. 

Alternatively, you can configure it yourself. Make sure `plugin.path` for your Kafka Connect worker(s) is set to include the folder in which you have the MongoDB sink connector JAR.

answers.body_markdown:
> If my way of thinking is correct function should return me `True && True && True` and when I use this combination in `ghci` it returns `True`.

Your `and' [True, True, True]` will boil down to <code>True && True && True && <b>and' []</b></code>. Since you did not write a clause for the empty list, it will thus fail. If there was a `False` in your list, then it would never really make that call to `and' []`, since `False && _` will return `False`, but a list that contains only `True`s will thus eventually make a call with the empty list.

You thus can fix the problem by handling the empty list case as well:

<pre><code>and' :: [Bool] -&gt; Bool
<b>and' [] = True</b>
and' (x:xs) = x && and' xs</code></pre>

If you turn on the [**`-Wincomplete-patterns`** warning [ghc-doc]](https://downloads.haskell.org/~ghc/latest/docs/html/users_guide/using-warnings.html#ghc-flag--Wincomplete-patterns), it will list the patterns you did not implement.

def positional_encoding(length, d_model):
    encoded_vec = tf.Variable([pos/tf.pow(10000, 2*i/d_model) for pos in range(length) for i in range(d_model)],

class Embedding(tf.keras.layers.Layer):
    def __init__(self, vocab_size, d_model, dropout=0.1):
        super().__init__()
        self.d_model = d_model
        self.token_embedding = tf.keras.layers.Embedding(vocab_size, d_model)
        self.positional_encoding = positional_encoding(vocab_size, d_model)
        self.dropout = tf.keras.layers.Dropout(dropout)
    
    def call(self, x):
        seq_len = tf.shape(x)[1]
        x = self.token_embedding(x)
        x *= tf.math.sqrt(tf.cast(self.d_model, tf.float32))
        x += self.positional_encoding[:, :seq_len, :]
        x = self.dropout(x)

answers.body_markdown:
Well, after a while I figure out the solution.

The first parameter of the serverless.yml file is `service: myService`. 

Changing that parameter actually generates a deployment which creates different endpoint.
answers.title: Deploy the same function to different endpoint on ASW Lambda

answers.body_markdown:
Changing the service name is not a very scalable solution. You should retain the same service name and deploy using a different --stage to get a different endpoint depending on the stage it's deployed to. You can use the stage to manage environment variables so that it can be set to one value on one stage and another value on another stage. See an example in [this SO Question][1]. Also, nodejs8.10 is EOL on AWS. Use nodejs10.x instead.


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50895367/how-to-create-multiple-stages-in-serverless-framwork
answers.title: Deploy the same function to different endpoint on ASW Lambda

    Total Working Days = 
    VAR maxMonth = MAX(Calendar[Business Month])
    VAR minMonth = MIN(Calendar[Business Month])
    RETURN

    #result = cv2.fastNlMeansDenoisingColored(img,None,20,10,7,21)
    rot = rotate(img, -5, reshape=False)
    cv2.imshow("rotate", rot)
    tessdata_dir_config = "/usr/share/tesseract-ocr/4.00/tessdata/"
    text=pytesseract.image_to_string(rot,lang='eng',config=tessdata_dir_config)
    carReg = anv.catch_rectify_plate_characters(text)
    print(carReg)
    cv2.waitKey(delay = 0)

   
Here i write the code for number recognition from number plate images,but the tessaract failed to recognize number. I have day light and night images. in most of the case ocr failed on night images. also i apply various filter filter for images clearing and also rotate the image angle for some degree.
